title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: ====Eastern Mediterranean====

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: President Biden inherited an economy in January 2021 that was at a record low on many key measures, such as [[Unemployment in the United States|unemployment levels]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf|title=THE EMPLOYMENT SITUATION —DECEMBER 2020|publisher=[[United States Department of Labor]]|date=January 8, 2021|access-date=January 20, 2021}}</ref> and increasing debt held by the public.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.treasurydirect.gov/govt/reports/pd/pd_debttothepenny.htm|title=The Debt to the Penny and Who Holds It|date=June 20, 2020|website=treasurydirect.gov|access-date=June 20, 2020}}</ref>

On January 22, 2021, Biden signed an [[executive order]] that removed schedule F, overturning a number of Trump's policies that limited the [[collective bargaining]] power of federal unions.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wagner |first1=Erich |title=Biden to Sign Executive Order Killing Schedule F, Restoring Collective Bargaining Rights |url=https://www.govexec.com/management/2021/01/biden-sign-executive-order-killing-schedule-f-restoring-collective-bargaining-rights/171569/ |access-date=22 January 2021 |work=Government Executive |date=January 22, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Ogrysko |first1=Nicole |title=Biden to repeal Schedule F, overturn Trump workforce policies with new executive order |url=https://federalnewsnetwork.com/workforce/2021/01/biden-to-repeal-schedule-f-overturn-trump-workforce-policies-with-new-executive-order/ |access-date=22 January 2021 |work=Federal News Network |date=January 22, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Wagner |first1=Erich |title=As White House Steps Up Schedule F Implementation, ‘Lawmakers Don’t Get It’ |url=https://www.govexec.com/management/2020/12/white-house-steps-schedule-f-implementation-lawmakers-dont-get-it/170722/ |access-date=22 January 2021 |work=Government Executive |date=14 December 2020}}</ref> Schedule F is an [[IRS]] form used to report farm income and expenses.<ref>{{cite web |title=2019 Instructions for Schedule F |url=https://www.irs.gov/instructions/i1040sf |website=IRS |access-date=22 January 2021 |year=2019}}</ref> Bidens executive order also promotes a $15 [[minimum wage]] for federal workers and repeals three executive orders signed by Trump that made the employee discipline process stricter and restricted union representatives’ access to office space. As well as promoting a $15 minimum wage, Biden's executive order increases the amount of money going to the families of children who are missing meals because of school closures due to the pandemic by 15%.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Boak |first1=Josh |title=Biden’s executive actions for economic relief at a glance |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/bidens-executive-actions-for-economic-relief-at-a-glance/2021/01/22/fc4f89dc-5cf4-11eb-a849-6f9423a75ffd_story.html |access-date=22 January 2021 |work=Washington Post |date=22 January 2021}}</ref> The repealing of Trump's three executive orders comes as the orders were used to transfer civil servants and career scientists and replace them with employees friendly to the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lienhard |first1=Kelly |title=Biden Axes Trump’s EO That Made It Easier To Fire Career Scientists |url=https://insidehealthpolicy.com/daily-news/biden-axes-trump%E2%80%99s-eo-made-it-easier-fire-career-scientists |access-date=22 January 2021 |work=Inside Health Policy |date=22 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden

title: Presidency of Joe Biden

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: === Campaign finance reform and government ethics ===
==== Role of lobbyists ====

Biden signed Executive Order 13989, Ethic Commitments by Executive Branch Personnel, which set the follow lobbying restrictions for political appointees:<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-21|title=Executive Order on Ethics Commitments by Executive Branch Personnel|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-ethics-commitments-by-executive-branch-personnel/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref>

* banned from "accepting gifts from registered lobbyists or lobbying organizations for the duration of their service"<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-21|title=Executive Order on Ethics Commitments by Executive Branch Personnel|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-ethics-commitments-by-executive-branch-personnel/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref>

* banned for 2 years from the date of their appointment to "participate in any particular matter involving specific parties that is directly and substantially related to ... former employers or former clients, including regulations and contracts"<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-21|title=Executive Order on Ethics Commitments by Executive Branch Personnel|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-ethics-commitments-by-executive-branch-personnel/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref>

* banned for 1 year following the end of my appointment to "assist others in making communications or appearances that [they] am prohibited from undertaking by being available to engage in lobbying activities in support of any such communications or appearances; or engaging in any such lobbying activities"<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-21|title=Executive Order on Ethics Commitments by Executive Branch Personnel|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-ethics-commitments-by-executive-branch-personnel/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref>

* banned from lobbying "any covered executive branch official or non-career Senior Executive Service appointee, or engage in any activity on behalf of any foreign government or foreign political party which ... for the remainder of the Administration or 2 years following the end of [their] appointment, whichever is later." after government service<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-21|title=Executive Order on Ethics Commitments by Executive Branch Personnel|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-ethics-commitments-by-executive-branch-personnel/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref>

* banned from "accepting any salary or other cash payment from [former employers] the eligibility for and payment of which is limited to individuals accepting a position in the United States Government, as well as any non-cash benefit from [former employers] that is provided in lieu of such a prohibited cash payment."<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-21|title=Executive Order on Ethics Commitments by Executive Branch Personnel|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-ethics-commitments-by-executive-branch-personnel/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref>
==== DOJ independence ====

Executive Order 13989 also stated the commitments of political appointees to conduct that upholds the independence of law enforcement and precludes improper interference with investigative or prosecutorial decisions of the Department of Justice.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-21|title=Executive Order on Ethics Commitments by Executive Branch Personnel|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-ethics-commitments-by-executive-branch-personnel/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref> Biden promised during the campaign trail that [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[Merrick Garland]] would work for the American people and not as the President's personal lawyer.
==== Transparency and data availability ====

Biden restarted the usual routine of daily press briefings that had been stopped by the Trump administration during the COVID-19 pandemic in light of frequent criticisms and gaffes.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Morin|first=Rebecca|title=Meet Jen Psaki: Here's what to know about President Biden's press secretary|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/01/21/jen-psaki-is-white-house-press-secretary-for-joe-biden-administration/4243255001/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=USA TODAY|language=en-US}}</ref> In the Biden administration's first press briefing, [[White House Press Secretary|White House press secretary]] [[Jen Psaki]] stated that her focus was on "bringing truth and transparency back to the briefing room" and that she had a "deep respect for the role of a free and independent press in our democracy and for the role all of [them] play".<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-21|title='I also work for the American people': Biden's press secretary to hold daily White House briefings|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-21/first-white-house-press-briefing-jen-psaki-biden-trump/13078034|access-date=2021-01-23|website=www.abc.net.au|language=en-AU}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: === Electoral and ethicsreformpolicy ===
{{See also|Electoral and ethics reform policy of the Joe Biden administration}}

In a reversal of the prevalent lack of ethics in the Trump administration, and the growing influence of special interests in federal and elections, the Joe Biden administration pledge [[Electoral reform in the United States|electoral reform]] and [[Public sector ethics|ethics reform.]]

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
deleted: == Impeachment efforts ==
{{see also|Efforts to impeach Joe Biden|Impeachment inquiry against Joe Biden}}

On January 21, 2021, [[Georgia (U.S. State)|Georgia]] [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] and conspiracy theorist [[Marjorie Taylor Greene]] introduced six articles of [[impeachment]] against President Biden, although the articles  were not made publicly available. Greene stated that she had filed the articles due to actions taken by Biden when he was previously Vice President in the Obama administration.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Marcos |first1=Christina |title=Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene files articles of impeachment against Biden |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/535317-rep-marjorie-taylor-greene-files-articles-of-impeachment-against-biden |access-date=January 21, 2021 |work=The Hill |date=January 21, 2021}}</ref> A 2020 investigation into corruption allegations regarding Biden and his son Hunter, led by Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee Chairman [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Ron Johnson]], a Republican, found no evidence of wrongdoing.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Carney |first1=Jordain |title=Top GOP senators say Hunter Biden's work 'cast a shadow' over Obama Ukraine policy |url=https://thehill.com/policy/national-security/517723-top-gop-senators-release-findings-from-controversial-biden-probe |access-date=January 21, 2021 |work=The Hill |date=September 9, 2020}}</ref> Additionally, a sitting president must be impeached for crimes that they may have committed while in the presidency rather than before they assumed office.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ellis |first1=C. M. |date=January 1867 |title=The Causes for Which a President Can Be Impeached |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1867/01/the-causes-for-which-a-president-can-be-impeached/548144/ |website=The Atlantic |access-date=January 23, 2021}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
deleted: In a reversal of the prevalent lack of ethics in the Trump administration, and the growing influence of special interests in federal and elections, the Joe Biden administration pledge reform on elections and government ethics.{{Citation needed|date=January 2021|reason=This claim needs a reliable source}}

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: The Joe Biden administration aims for massive spending on the nation's infrastructure on the order of $2 trillion.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Henry|first=Jim|date=2021-01-20|title=Biden Infrastructure Plan Pushes Better Roads, EV Chargers, Mass Transit|url=https://www.forbes.com/wheels/news/biden-infrastructure-plan-better-roads-ev-chargers-mass-transit/|access-date=2021-01-25|website=Forbes Wheels|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: In a reversal of the frequent ethics violations of the Trump administration, the Joe Biden administration pledged to pass government ethics reform.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-10-19|title=President Trump's worst offenses|url=https://www.citizensforethics.org/news/analysis/president-trumps-worst-offenses/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=CREW {{!}} Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Plan for a Government that Works For the People {{!}} Joe Biden|url=https://joebiden.com/governmentreform/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=Joe Biden for President: Official Campaign Website|language=en-US}}</ref> In response to the growing influence of special interests and gerrymandering in elections, the Biden administration also pledged to pass legislation and enforce policies to enforce electoral reform.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Plan for a Government that Works For the People {{!}} Joe Biden|url=https://joebiden.com/governmentreform/|access-date=2021-01-23|website=Joe Biden for President: Official Campaign Website|language=en-US}}</ref>

The Joe Biden administration aims for massive spending on the nation's infrastructure on the order of $2 trillion.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Henry|first=Jim|date=2021-01-20|title=Biden Infrastructure Plan Pushes Better Roads, EV Chargers, Mass Transit|url=https://www.forbes.com/wheels/news/biden-infrastructure-plan-better-roads-ev-chargers-mass-transit/|access-date=2021-01-25|website=Forbes Wheels|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: On February 1, 2021, Biden condemned the [[2021 Myanmar coup d'état|Myanmar coup d'état]] and called for the release of detained officials. Biden also threatened to impose sanctions on coup perpetrators, saying in a statement that the United States would initiate "an immediate review of our sanction laws and authorities, followed by appropriate action." <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/01/31/statement-by-white-house-spokesperson-jen-psaki-on-burma/|title=Statement by White House Spokesperson Jen Psaki on Burma|date=1 February 2021|website=The White House}}</ref><ref>{{Cite tweet |user=ZekeJMiller |number=1356293569674440704 |title=Biden statement on Burma: "The United States removed sanctions on Burma over the past decade based on progress toward democracy. The reversal of that progress will necessitate an immediate review of our sanction laws and authorities, followed by appropriate action."

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: On his first day in office, Biden established the position of [[White House National Climate Advisor]], appointing [[environmental health]] and [[air quality]] expert [[Gina McCarthy]] to the role. Biden also created the position of [[U.S. Special Presidential Envoy for Climate]], appointing former Secretary of State [[John Kerry]]. <ref>{{cite web |title=Executive Order on Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/27/executive-order-on-tackling-the-climate-crisis-at-home-and-abroad/ |website=The White House |date=27 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: Duringhis firstweekin office, Biden established the position of [[White House National Climate Advisor]], appointing [[environmental health]] and [[air quality]] expert [[Gina McCarthy]] to the role. Biden also created the position of [[U.S. Special Presidential Envoy for Climate]], appointing former Secretary of State [[John Kerry]]. <ref>{{cite web |title=Executive Order on Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/27/executive-order-on-tackling-the-climate-crisis-at-home-and-abroad/ |website=The White House |date=27 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
deleted: ==Space policy==

White House press secretary [[Jen Psaki]] said the [[United States Space Force|Space Force]] “absolutely has the full support of the Biden administration″ on February 3, 2021, following earlier remarks in which she expressed some doubts.<ref>{{cite news |title=White House: Space Force “absolutely has the full support of the Biden administration” |url=https://spacenews.com/white-house-space-force-absolutely-has-the-full-support-of-the-biden-administration/ |access-date=February 7, 2021 |work=SpaceNews |date=3 February 2021}}</ref> The next day she said that the administration supported NASA′s [[Artemis program]] of landing men and women on the moon and possibly Mars, although the 2024 lunar landing date was left unclear.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Whittington |first1=Mark |title=The Biden administration endorses NASA's Artemis, the Space Force |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/the-biden-administration-endorses-nasa-s-artemis-the-space-force/ar-BB1dthws?ocid=ob-fb-enus-1541512262291 |access-date=February 7, 2021 |work=msn.com |publisher=The Hill |date=February 7, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Fourst |first1=Jeff |title=White House endorses Artemis program |url=https://spacenews.com/white-house-endorses-artemis-program/ |access-date=February 7, 2021 |work=SpaceNews |date=4 February 2021}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: == Transition period and inauguration ==
{{Main|Presidential transition of Joe Biden}}

Two days after becoming the projected winner, Biden announced the formation of a task force, co-chaired by former surgeon general [[Vivek Murthy]], former FDA commissioner [[David A. Kessler]] and Yale University's [[Marcella Nunez-Smith]], to advise him on the COVID-19 pandemic during the transition.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Sarah Mucha and Eric Bradner|title=Biden transition team announces coronavirus advisers, including whistleblower Rick Bright|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/09/politics/biden-coronavirus-advisers-experts-rick-bright/index.html|access-date=November 12, 2020|website=CNN}}</ref>

On November 11, 2020, Biden chose [[Ron Klain]] (who was Biden's chief of staff during his vice-presidency) to be his White House chief of staff.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Shear |first1=Michael D. |last2=Glueck |first2=Katie |last3=Haberman|first3=Maggie |last4=Kaplan|first4=Thomas| date=November 12, 2020|title=Biden Names Ron Klain as White House Chief of Staff |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/11/us/politics/ron-klain-biden.html|access-date=November 12, 2020 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

On November 17, 2020, Biden announced that he had selected [[Mike Donilon]] as senior advisor and [[Steve Ricchetti]] as counselor.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Sullivan |first=Sean |date=November 17, 2020 |title=Biden builds White House team and tries to show dangers of Trump's intransigence |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/biden-transition-trump/2020/11/17/cfb8a5c2-28ef-11eb-9b14-ad872157ebc9_story.html|access-date=November 21, 2020}}</ref> [[Jen O'Malley Dillon|Jennifer O'Malley Dillon]], who had served as campaign manager for Biden's successful presidential campaign, was named as deputy chief of staff.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Lerer |first=Lisa |date=November 17, 2020 |title=Jennifer O'Malley Dillon, Biden's Campaign Manager, Will Tackle Another Difficult Job |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/17/us/politics/jennifer-omalley-dillon-biden.html|access-date=November 21, 2020}}</ref> President-elect Biden planned to announce his first nominees to the [[Cabinet of the United States|Cabinet]] before [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] 2020.<ref>{{cite news |last=Jaffe |first=Alexandra |title=Biden Could Announce Cabinet Picks as Soon as Next Week |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2020-11-20/biden-could-announce-cabinet-picks-as-soon-as-next-week |access-date=November 22, 2020 |work=US News & World Report |date=November 20, 2020}}</ref> On November 22, 2020, several news outlets reported that Biden had selected [[Antony Blinken]] to be secretary of state, [[Linda Thomas-Greenfield]] as ambassador to the United Nations, and [[Jake Sullivan]] as national security advisor.<ref>{{cite news |last=Jakes |first=Lara |title=Biden Chooses Antony Blinken, Defender of Global Alliances, as Secretary of State |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/22/us/politics/biden-antony-blinken-secretary-of-state.html |access-date=November 22, 2020 |work=The New York Times |date=November 22, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Linskey |first=Annie |title=Biden to nominate Antony Blinken as secretary of state, Linda Thomas-Greenfield as U.N. ambassador |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/11/22/joe-biden-nominate-antony-blinken-secretary-state/ |access-date=November 22, 2020 |work=The Washington Post |date=November 22, 2020}}</ref>

On November 23, 2020, Biden picked [[John Kerry]] to be his [[U.S. Special Presidential Envoy for Climate|climate change envoy]],<ref>{{Cite web|title=Biden picks John Kerry as climate czar, Alejandro Mayorkas for Homeland Security|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/biden-harris-meet-mayors-covid-cases-soar-n1248596 |access-date=November 23, 2020|website=NBC News|language=en}}</ref> [[Alejandro Mayorkas]] to be [[Secretary of Homeland Security]] and [[Avril Haines]] as [[Director of National Intelligence]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Crowley |first1=Michael |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/23/us/politics/biden-nominees.html |title=Biden Will Nominate First Woman to Lead Intelligence, First Latino to Run Homeland Security|access-date=November 23, 2020 |work=The New York Times |date=November 23, 2020}}</ref> Throughout December and January, Biden continued to pick his cabinet members, such as [[Marty Walsh (politician)|Marty Walsh]], the current mayor of Boston, as his [[United States Secretary of Labor|secretary of labor]] pick.

On January 20, 2021, [[Joe Biden]] was sworn in by [[Chief Justice of the United States]] [[John Roberts]] as 46th [[president of the United States]], completing the [[Oath of office of the president of the United States|oath of office]] at 11:49 AM EST, eleven minutes before the legal start of his term.<ref>{{cite news |title=Biden Inaugurated as the 46th President Amid a Cascade of Crises |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/20/us/politics/biden-president.html|access-date=January 20, 2021 |work=New York Times}}</ref>

While administering the oath of office to hundreds of White House officials through [[video conferencing]], Biden called for more [[civility]] in politics, saying: "If you ever work with me and I hear you treat another colleague with disrespect, talk down to someone, I promise you I will fire you on the spot. [...] No ifs, ands, or buts."<ref>{{cite news |last=Aggarwal |first=Mayank |title=Biden tells staff he will 'fire them on the spot' if they show disrespect to colleagues |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/biden-fire-staff-spot-disrespect-colleagues-b1790476.html |access-date=January 21, 2021 |work=The Independent |date=January 21, 2021 |language=en}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
deleted: Biden announced that he would run for president in April 2019, via a video and following two unsuccessful presidential campaigns in [[Joe Biden 1988 presidential campaign|1988]] and [[Joe Biden 2008 presidential campaign|2008]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Cohn|first=Nate|date=July 16, 2020|title=One Year From Election, Trump Trails Biden but Leads Warren in Battlegrounds (Published 2019)|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/04/upshot/trump-biden-warren-polls.html|access-date=November 8, 2020|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: == Public approval & Historical evaluation ==

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: == Public opinion ==
=== Popular polling ===

Opinion polls have found that Joe Biden's approval ratings have been steadier then Trump's with an average approval rating of 55% and an average disapproval rate of 39%.<ref>{{Cite web|last=CNN|first=Analysis by Harry Enten|title=Analysis: Biden's polling is steadier than Trump's|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/21/politics/biden-approval-poll-of-the-week/index.html|access-date=2021-02-25|website=CNN}}</ref> Joe Biden approval ratings have been more polarized then Trump's with Gallup saying that 98% of democrats, 61% of independents and 11% of republicans approved of Joe Biden's presidency in February 2021 a party gap of 87%.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Inc|first=Gallup|date=2021-02-04|title=Biden Begins Term With 57% Job Approval|url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/329348/biden-begins-term-job-approval.aspx|access-date=2021-02-25|website=Gallup.com|language=en}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: ==Foreign affairs==
{{main|Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration}}
{{see also|Antony Blinken#Foreign policy}}
===Defense===

On January 22, 2021, Biden signed his first bill,<ref name="Hoffman" /> H.R. 335 into law providing an exception to a restriction on appointing a [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] who, within the past seven years, had been on active duty in the [[United States Army|armed forces]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bill Signing: H.R. 335 |website=The White House |date=January 22, 2021 |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/legislation/2021/01/22/bill-signing-hr-335/ |access-date=January 22, 2021}}</ref> The signing of H.R. 335 made it possible for retired army [[Four-star rank|four-star]] [[General (United States)|general]] [[Lloyd Austin]] to serve as Biden's Secretary of Defense. Austin was confirmed by both the [[United States Senate|Senate]] in a 93–2 vote that same day, making Austin the first [[African Americans|African American]] Defense Secretary.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Foran |first1=Clare |title=Senate confirms Lloyd Austin to be first Black defense secretary |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/22/politics/lloyd-austin-senate-vote-confirmation/index.html |access-date=January 22, 2021 |work=CNN |date=January 22, 2021}}</ref><ref name="Hoffman">{{cite news |last=Hoffman |first=Jason |title=Biden signs first bill into law as President, granting a waiver to his Defense pick |url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/president-joe-biden-news-01-22-20/h_5cd510d89040f6be531921b3f7ac077d |access-date=January 22, 2021 |work=CNN |date=January 22, 2021}}</ref>

Austin has stated his number one priority is to assist [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19]] relief efforts, pledging he would "quickly review the Department's contributions to coronavirus relief efforts, ensuring that we're doing everything that we can to help distribute vaccines across the country and to vaccinate our troops and preserve readiness."<ref>{{cite news |title=WATCH: Gen. Lloyd Austin’s full opening statement in Senate confirmation hearing {{!}} WPBS {{!}} Serving Northern New York and Eastern Ontario |url=https://www.wpbstv.org/watch-gen-lloyd-austins-full-opening-statement-in-senate-confirmation-hearing/ |work=WPBS |date=19 January 2021}}</ref>

When asked, press secretary Psaki said the [[United States Space Force|Space Force]] "absolutely has the full support of the Biden administration" following earlier remarks in which she expressed some doubts.<ref>{{cite news |title=White House: Space Force "absolutely has the full support of the Biden administration" |url=https://spacenews.com/white-house-space-force-absolutely-has-the-full-support-of-the-biden-administration/ |access-date=February 7, 2021 |work=SpaceNews |date=3 February 2021}}</ref>

On February 10, 2021, Biden visited [[The Pentagon]] for the first time as President.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stewart |first1=Phil |last2=Holland |first2=Steve |title=In Pentagon debut, Biden promises break from Trump-era politicization of military |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-defense-idUSKBN2AA2X2 |work=Reuters |date=10 February 2021 |language=en}}</ref> In remarks to service members alongside Vice President [[Kamala Harris]] and Defense Secretary [[Lloyd Austin]], Biden announced a [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] led China task force to "to provide a baseline assessment of department policies, programs and processes in regard to the challenge China poses." <ref>{{cite web |title=Biden Announces DOD China Task Force |url=https://www.defense.gov/Explore/News/Article/Article/2500271/biden-announces-dod-china-task-force/ |website=U.S. DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE}}</ref>
===China===

Biden has said the U.S. needs to "get tough" on China and build "a united front of U.S. allies and partners to confront China’s abusive behaviors and human rights violations."<ref name="fore_Why_America">{{Cite web |title=Why America Must Lead Again |last=Biden |first=Joseph R. |magazine=[[Foreign Affairs]] |date=January 23, 2020 |access-date=January 29, 2021 |url= https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/united-states/2020-01-23/why-america-must-lead-again}}</ref> He described China as the "most serious competitor" that poses challenges on the "prosperity, security, and democratic values" of the U.S.<ref name="whit_Remarks_by">{{Cite web |title=Remarks by President Biden on America's Place in the World |author= |publisher=[[The White House]] |date=February 4, 2021 |access-date=February 6, 2021 |url= https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2021/02/04/remarks-by-president-biden-on-americas-place-in-the-world/}}</ref>

Biden nominated [[Antony Blinken]] to serve as Secretary of State who took office on January 26, 2021.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hansler |first1=Jennifer |title=Antony Blinken sworn in as Biden's secretary of state |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/26/politics/blinken-confirmation-secretary-of-state/index.html |access-date=January 28, 2021 |work=CNN |date=January 26, 2021}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|last=Bernstein|first=Brittany|date=January 20, 2021|title=Incoming Secretary of State Backs Pompeo's Uyghur Genocide Designation|work=[[National Review]]|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/news/incoming-secretary-of-state-backs-pompeos-uyghur-genocide-designation/|url-status=live|access-date=}}</ref> During his nomination hearing, Blinken stated that previous optimistic approaches to China were flawed,<ref name="wsj._Blinken_Backs">{{Cite web |title=Blinken Backs Tough Approach to China, Says Will Work With GOP |last1=Mauldin |first1=William |last2=Gordon |first2=Michael R. |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=January 20, 2021 |access-date=January 28, 2021 |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/blinken-to-address-u-s-rivalry-with-china-russia-in-senate-hearing-11611069439?mod=article_inline}}</ref> and that Biden's predecessor, Donald Trump, "was right in taking a tougher approach to China", but that he "disagree[s] very much with the way [Trump] went about it in a number of areas."<ref name=":2" /> He endorsed former Secretary of State [[Mike Pompeo]]'s report that China is committing a [[Uyghur genocide|genocide against Uyghur Muslims]].<ref name=":2" />
===Myanmar===

On February 1, 2021, Biden condemned the [[2021 Myanmar coup d'état|Myanmar coup d'état]] and called for the release of detained officials. Biden also left open the door to re-imposing sanctions on the country, saying in a statement that "[t]he United States removed sanctions on Burma over the past decade based on progress toward democracy. The reversal of that progress will necessitate an immediate review of our sanction laws and authorities, followed by appropriate action." <ref>{{Cite news|last=Hansler|first=Jennifer|date=3 February 2021|title=Biden administration designates Myanmar military takeover as a coup|work=[[CNN]]|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/02/politics/myanmar-state-department-coup-determination/index.html|url-status=live|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=McLaughlin|first=Timothy|date=2 February 2020|title=Joe Biden’s Challenge Was Barack Obama’s Victory|work=[[The Atlantic]]|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2021/02/myanmar-coup-aung-san-suu-kyi/617887/|url-status=live|access-date=}}</ref>
===Saudi Arabia===

Biden ordered a halt in the arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates which the Trump administration had previously agreed to.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021|title=Biden administration halts arms sales to UAE and Saudi Arabia|url=https://www.dw.com/en/biden-administration-halts-arms-sales-to-uae-and-saudi-arabia/a-56365478|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 30, 2021|website=DW.COM|language=en-GB}}</ref> Two years after [[Assassination of Jamal Khashoggi|Jamal Khashoggi's assassination]], Avril Haines, the [[Director of National Intelligence]] under Biden’s administration, announced that the intelligence report into the case against [[Saudi Arabia]]'s government will be declassified. It was reported that Crown Prince [[Mohammed bin Salman]] would be blamed for the murder, as was concluded by the [[CIA]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jan/19/biden-administration-to-declassify-report-into-khashoggi|title=Biden administration 'to declassify report' into Khashoggi murder|access-date=January 19, 2021|website=The Guardian}}</ref>
===Yemen===

On February 4, 2021, the Biden Administration announced that the United States was ending its support for the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|Saudi-led bombing campaign]] in [[Yemen]]. President Biden in his first visit to the State Department as president said "this war has to end" and that the conflict has created a "humanitarian and strategic catastrophe".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Knickmeyer |first1=Ellen |date=February 5, 2021 |title=Biden ending US support for Saudi-led offensive in Yemen |url=https://apnews.com/article/biden-end-support-saudi-offenseive-yemen-b68f58493dbfc530b9fcfdb80a13098f |website=Associated Press |access-date=February 5, 2021}}</ref>
===Paris Climate Accord===

The administration will make tackling global [[climate change]] a priority for U.S. national security and foreign policy.<ref name="abcn_Bideb_says">{{Cite web |title=Biden says tackling climate change will create jobs, bring economic recovery |last1=Ebbs |first1=Stephanie |last2=Kolinovsky |first2=Sarah |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=January 27, 2021 |access-date=January 28, 2021 |url= https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/biden-sign-executive-order-climate-change/story?id=75510742}}</ref> Immediately after becoming president, Biden rejoined the [[Paris Agreement|Paris Climate Accord]].
===Worldwide LGBT rights===

On February 4, 2021, Biden issued a presidential memorandum for expanding protection of the [[LGBT community|LGBTQI]] rights worldwide, which includes the possibility to impose financial sanctions.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Shalal|first=Alexandra Alper, Andrea|date=2021-02-05|title=Biden calls for expanded efforts to protect LGBTQ rights globally|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-lgbt-idUSKBN2A42KF|access-date=2021-02-21}}</ref>
==Foreign affairs==
{{main|Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration}}
{{see also|Antony Blinken#Foreign policy}}
===Defense===

On January 22, 2021, Biden signed his first bill,<ref name="Hoffman" /> H.R. 335 into law providing an exception to a restriction on appointing a [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] who, within the past seven years, had been on active duty in the [[United States Army|armed forces]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bill Signing: H.R. 335 |website=The White House |date=January 22, 2021 |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/legislation/2021/01/22/bill-signing-hr-335/ |access-date=January 22, 2021}}</ref> The signing of H.R. 335 made it possible for retired army [[Four-star rank|four-star]] [[General (United States)|general]] [[Lloyd Austin]] to serve as Biden's Secretary of Defense. Austin was confirmed by both the [[United States Senate|Senate]] in a 93–2 vote that same day, making Austin the first [[African Americans|African American]] Defense Secretary.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Foran |first1=Clare |title=Senate confirms Lloyd Austin to be first Black defense secretary |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/22/politics/lloyd-austin-senate-vote-confirmation/index.html |access-date=January 22, 2021 |work=CNN |date=January 22, 2021}}</ref><ref name="Hoffman">{{cite news |last=Hoffman |first=Jason |title=Biden signs first bill into law as President, granting a waiver to his Defense pick |url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/president-joe-biden-news-01-22-20/h_5cd510d89040f6be531921b3f7ac077d |access-date=January 22, 2021 |work=CNN |date=January 22, 2021}}</ref>

Austin has stated his number one priority is to assist [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19]] relief efforts, pledging he would "quickly review the Department's contributions to coronavirus relief efforts, ensuring that we're doing everything that we can to help distribute vaccines across the country and to vaccinate our troops and preserve readiness."<ref>{{cite news |title=WATCH: Gen. Lloyd Austin’s full opening statement in Senate confirmation hearing {{!}} WPBS {{!}} Serving Northern New York and Eastern Ontario |url=https://www.wpbstv.org/watch-gen-lloyd-austins-full-opening-statement-in-senate-confirmation-hearing/ |work=WPBS |date=19 January 2021}}</ref>

When asked, press secretary Psaki said the [[United States Space Force|Space Force]] "absolutely has the full support of the Biden administration" following earlier remarks in which she expressed some doubts.<ref>{{cite news |title=White House: Space Force "absolutely has the full support of the Biden administration" |url=https://spacenews.com/white-house-space-force-absolutely-has-the-full-support-of-the-biden-administration/ |access-date=February 7, 2021 |work=SpaceNews |date=3 February 2021}}</ref>

On February 10, 2021, Biden visited [[The Pentagon]] for the first time as President.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stewart |first1=Phil |last2=Holland |first2=Steve |title=In Pentagon debut, Biden promises break from Trump-era politicization of military |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-defense-idUSKBN2AA2X2 |work=Reuters |date=10 February 2021 |language=en}}</ref> In remarks to service members alongside Vice President [[Kamala Harris]] and Defense Secretary [[Lloyd Austin]], Biden announced a [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] led China task force to "to provide a baseline assessment of department policies, programs and processes in regard to the challenge China poses." <ref>{{cite web |title=Biden Announces DOD China Task Force |url=https://www.defense.gov/Explore/News/Article/Article/2500271/biden-announces-dod-china-task-force/ |website=U.S. DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE}}</ref>
===China===

Biden has said the U.S. needs to "get tough" on China and build "a united front of U.S. allies and partners to confront China’s abusive behaviors and human rights violations."<ref name="fore_Why_America">{{Cite web |title=Why America Must Lead Again |last=Biden |first=Joseph R. |magazine=[[Foreign Affairs]] |date=January 23, 2020 |access-date=January 29, 2021 |url= https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/united-states/2020-01-23/why-america-must-lead-again}}</ref> He described China as the "most serious competitor" that poses challenges on the "prosperity, security, and democratic values" of the U.S.<ref name="whit_Remarks_by">{{Cite web |title=Remarks by President Biden on America's Place in the World |author= |publisher=[[The White House]] |date=February 4, 2021 |access-date=February 6, 2021 |url= https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2021/02/04/remarks-by-president-biden-on-americas-place-in-the-world/}}</ref>

Biden nominated [[Antony Blinken]] to serve as Secretary of State who took office on January 26, 2021.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hansler |first1=Jennifer |title=Antony Blinken sworn in as Biden's secretary of state |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/26/politics/blinken-confirmation-secretary-of-state/index.html |access-date=January 28, 2021 |work=CNN |date=January 26, 2021}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|last=Bernstein|first=Brittany|date=January 20, 2021|title=Incoming Secretary of State Backs Pompeo's Uyghur Genocide Designation|work=[[National Review]]|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/news/incoming-secretary-of-state-backs-pompeos-uyghur-genocide-designation/|url-status=live|access-date=}}</ref> During his nomination hearing, Blinken stated that previous optimistic approaches to China were flawed,<ref name="wsj._Blinken_Backs">{{Cite web |title=Blinken Backs Tough Approach to China, Says Will Work With GOP |last1=Mauldin |first1=William |last2=Gordon |first2=Michael R. |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=January 20, 2021 |access-date=January 28, 2021 |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/blinken-to-address-u-s-rivalry-with-china-russia-in-senate-hearing-11611069439?mod=article_inline}}</ref> and that Biden's predecessor, Donald Trump, "was right in taking a tougher approach to China", but that he "disagree[s] very much with the way [Trump] went about it in a number of areas."<ref name=":2" /> He endorsed former Secretary of State [[Mike Pompeo]]'s report that China is committing a [[Uyghur genocide|genocide against Uyghur Muslims]].<ref name=":2" />
===Myanmar===

On February 1, 2021, Biden condemned the [[2021 Myanmar coup d'état|Myanmar coup d'état]] and called for the release of detained officials. Biden also left open the door to re-imposing sanctions on the country, saying in a statement that "[t]he United States removed sanctions on Burma over the past decade based on progress toward democracy. The reversal of that progress will necessitate an immediate review of our sanction laws and authorities, followed by appropriate action." <ref>{{Cite news|last=Hansler|first=Jennifer|date=3 February 2021|title=Biden administration designates Myanmar military takeover as a coup|work=[[CNN]]|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/02/politics/myanmar-state-department-coup-determination/index.html|url-status=live|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=McLaughlin|first=Timothy|date=2 February 2020|title=Joe Biden’s Challenge Was Barack Obama’s Victory|work=[[The Atlantic]]|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2021/02/myanmar-coup-aung-san-suu-kyi/617887/|url-status=live|access-date=}}</ref>
===Saudi Arabia===

Biden ordered a halt in the arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates which the Trump administration had previously agreed to.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021|title=Biden administration halts arms sales to UAE and Saudi Arabia|url=https://www.dw.com/en/biden-administration-halts-arms-sales-to-uae-and-saudi-arabia/a-56365478|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 30, 2021|website=DW.COM|language=en-GB}}</ref> Two years after [[Assassination of Jamal Khashoggi|Jamal Khashoggi's assassination]], Avril Haines, the [[Director of National Intelligence]] under Biden’s administration, announced that the intelligence report into the case against [[Saudi Arabia]]'s government will be declassified. It was reported that Crown Prince [[Mohammed bin Salman]] would be blamed for the murder, as was concluded by the [[CIA]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/jan/19/biden-administration-to-declassify-report-into-khashoggi|title=Biden administration 'to declassify report' into Khashoggi murder|access-date=January 19, 2021|website=The Guardian}}</ref>

On February 4, 2021, the Biden Administration announced that the United States was ending its support for the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|Saudi-led bombing campaign]] in [[Yemen]]. President Biden in his first visit to the State Department as president said "this war has to end" and that the conflict has created a "humanitarian and strategic catastrophe".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Knickmeyer |first1=Ellen |date=February 5, 2021 |title=Biden ending US support for Saudi-led offensive in Yemen |url=https://apnews.com/article/biden-end-support-saudi-offenseive-yemen-b68f58493dbfc530b9fcfdb80a13098f |website=Associated Press |access-date=February 5, 2021}}</ref>
===Paris Climate Accord===

The administration will make tackling global [[climate change]] a priority for U.S. national security and foreign policy.<ref name="abcn_Bideb_says">{{Cite web |title=Biden says tackling climate change will create jobs, bring economic recovery |last1=Ebbs |first1=Stephanie |last2=Kolinovsky |first2=Sarah |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=January 27, 2021 |access-date=January 28, 2021 |url= https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/biden-sign-executive-order-climate-change/story?id=75510742}}</ref> Immediately after becoming president, Biden rejoined the [[Paris Agreement|Paris Climate Accord]].

The administration will make tackling global [[climate change]] a priority for U.S. national security and foreign policy.<ref name="abcn_Bideb_says">{{Cite web |title=Biden says tackling climate change will create jobs, bring economic recovery |last1=Ebbs |first1=Stephanie |last2=Kolinovsky |first2=Sarah |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=January 27, 2021 |access-date=January 28, 2021 |url= https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/biden-sign-executive-order-climate-change/story?id=75510742}}</ref> Immediately after becoming president, Biden rejoined the [[Paris Agreement|Paris Climate Accord]].
===Worldwide LGBT rights===

On February 4, 2021, Biden issued a presidential memorandum for expanding protection of the [[LGBT community|LGBTQI]] rights worldwide, which includes the possibility to impose financial sanctions.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Shalal|first=Alexandra Alper, Andrea|date=2021-02-05|title=Biden calls for expanded efforts to protect LGBTQ rights globally|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-lgbt-idUSKBN2A42KF|access-date=2021-02-21}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: ===Space policy===

In a February 4, 2021 memo, the White House announced a change from the Trump administration's method of using the [[National Space Council]] to coordinate commercial, civil, and military space policies, instead using the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] for the same purpose. This means that national security memoranda will replace the Space Council's space policy directives. {{As of|2021|2|26}}, it is not known whether or not the Biden administration will keep the NSC. A coalition of 17 industry groups lobbied the White House chief of staff Klain to keep the National Space Council.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Erwin |first1=Sandra |title=White House to realign responsibilities for space policy oversight |url=https://spacenews.com/white-house-to-realign-responsibilities-for-space-policy-oversight/ |access-date=February 26, 2021 |work=SpaceNews |date=February 5, 2021}}</ref>

In the February 4 press briefing, Psaki expressed the Biden administration's support of the [[Artemis program]] to send people back to the Moon, though no details about funding levels or adherence to the 2024 first landing goal were given.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Foust |first1=Jeff |title=White House endorses Artemis program |url=https://spacenews.com/white-house-endorses-artemis-program/ |access-date=February 26, 2021 |work=SpaceNews |date=February 4, 2021}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: Early in his presidency, Biden ordered retaliatory air strikes against Syrian buildings used by Iranian millitias to stage rocket attacks against U.S. targets in Iraq. He also used executive orders to reverse President Trump's "America First" policy toward U.S. allies, and immediately restored U.S. participation in the [[Paris Agreement|Paris Climate Change Accord]]. He also issued an early series of executive orders to deal with COVID-19, setting a goal of achieving one million U.S. vaccinations in his first 100 days, and reversed Trump's policy on illegal southern border immigration.

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
deleted: In March 2021, the White House announced that President Biden will soon to be removed from office in June 2021 by Vice President [[Kamala Harris]] and Speaker [[Nancy Pelosi]] using the section 4 from the [[Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|25th Amendment]], due to his old age and health issues.

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: On January 6, a mob of thousands of Trump supporters violently broke into the Capitol in the hope of overturning Biden's election, forcing Congress to evacuate during the counting of the electoral college votes.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tan |first1=Rebecca |last2=Jamison |first2=Peter |last3=Leonnig |first3=Carol D. |last4=Flynn |first4=Meagan |last5=Cox |first5=John Woodrow |title=Trump supporters storm U.S. Capitol, with one woman killed and tear gas fired |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trump-supporters-storm-capitol-dc/2021/01/06/58afc0b8-504b-11eb-83e3-322644d82356_story.html |access-date=March 10, 2021 |work=The Washington Post |date=January 6, 2021}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: On the day of Biden's inauguration, the [[Russian government]] urged the new U.S. administration to take a "more constructive" approach in talks over the extension of the [[New START|2010 New START treaty]], the sole remaining agreement limiting the number of U.S. and Russian [[List of states with nuclear weapons|long-range nuclear warheads]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-20|title=Russia Urges Biden to Be 'More Constructive' Over Arms Treaty |url=https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/01/20/russia-urges-biden-to-be-more-constructive-over-arms-treaty-a72675 |website=[[The Moscow Times]]|language=en}}</ref> In Biden's first telephone call as president with [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Vladimir Putin]], on January 26, 2021, Biden and Putin agreed to extend the New START treaty (which was set to expire in February 2021) by an additional five years.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-27|title=Renewed US-Russia nuke pact won't fix emerging arms threats |url=https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-politics-nuclear-weapons-north-korea-vladimir-putin-41891565c23d7ff99f5c575080c7ed6a |access-date=2021-01-28|website=[[Associated Press]]|language=en}}</ref>

Biden and his administration condemned human rights violations by the Russian authorities, calling for the release of detained dissident and anti-corruption activist [[Alexei Navalny]], his wife, and the thousands of Russians who had [[2021 Russian protests|demonstrated in his support]]; the U.S. called for the unconditional release of Navalny and the protestors and a credible investigation into [[Poisoning of Alexei Navalny|Navalny's poisioning]].<ref>Ben Leonard & Thibault Larger, [https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/23/alexei-navalny-protests-arrests-461606 U.S. condemns Russia's arrests of Navalny protesters], ''Politico'' (January 23, 2021).</ref><ref>Morgan Chalfant, [https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/537429-biden-condemns-jailing-of-navalny-in-russia Biden condemns jailing of Navalny in Russia], ''The Hill'' (February 4, 2021).</ref><ref>[https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/russian-opposition-leader-navalny-back-court-biden-ups-pressure-moscow-n1256833 Russian opposition leader Navalny back in court as Biden ups pressure on Moscow], Reuters (February 5, 2021).</ref> On March 2, 2021, the U.S. and European Union imposed coordinated additional sanctions on Russian officials, as well as the [[Federal Security Service|FSB]] and [[GRU (G.U.)|GRU]], over Navalny poisoning and imprisonment. The State Department also expanded existing sanctions from the Chemical and Biological Weapons Control and Warfare Elimination Act that had been imposed after the poisoning of Skripal.<ref name=Hansler>{{Cite web|publisher=CNN|authors=Jennifer Hansler|title=Biden administration unveils raft of sanctions on Russia over Navalny poisoning and imprisonment|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/02/politics/biden-russia-sanctions-alexey-navalny/index.html|access-date=2021-03-04}}</ref>

The Biden administration is also planning to impose sanctions against Russia over [[2020 United States federal government data breach|2020 SolarWinds cyberespionage campaign]], which compromised the computer systems of nine federal agencies.<ref name=PreparingtoSanction>Ellen Nakashima, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/biden-russia-sanctions-solarwinds-hacks/2021/02/23/b77039d6-71fa-11eb-85fa-e0ccb3660358_story.html Biden administration preparing to sanction Russia for SolarWinds hacks and the poisoning of an opposition leader], ''Washington Post'' (February 23, 2021).</ref> Biden's national security adviser [[Jake Sullivan]] said that the response "will include a mix of tools seen and unseen, and it will not simply be sanctions."<ref name=PreparingtoSanction/><ref name=Hansler/>

The Biden administration's comprehensive review into Russian activities has included an examination of [[Russian bounty program|reports that the Russian government offered to Taliban-linked fighters to kill U.S. troops in Afghanistan]].<ref>Abigail Williams, Dan De Luce, Carol E. Lee and Andrea Mitchell, [https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/u-s-eu-set-impose-sanctions-russia-n1259249 U.S., E.U. impose sanctions on Russia over Navalny's poisoning], NBC News (March 2, 2021).</ref><ref>Lara Seligman, [https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/01/tammy-duckworth-biden-russian-bounties-471931 Duckworth urges Biden admin to release intel on Russian bounties], ''Politico'' (March 1, 2021).</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: On March 18, the administration nominated [[Bill Nelson]] as [[NASA administrator]] to replace Jim Bridenstine.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-03-19|title=President Biden Announces his Intent to Nominate Bill Nelson for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/19/president-biden-announces-his-intent-to-nominate-bill-nelson-for-the-national-aeronautics-and-space-administration/|access-date=2021-03-19|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Presidency of Joe Biden
added: On 27 March, Biden invited more than 40 world leaders for a climate summit.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-03-27|title=Biden invites Russia, China to first global climate talks|url=https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-donald-trump-barack-obama-climate-climate-change-d7ccfff957ff6cdf500d3bb7692ab5ff|url-status=live|access-date=2021-03-30|website=AP News}}</ref>
